DOC.HEAD: Thousands Surge Through as Berlin Wall Opens at Brandenburg Gate

DOC.TEXT:
Thousands of jubilant Berliners surged through new openings in the Berlin Wall at the Brandenburg Gate today for the first time in 28 years. The celebrants braved an intermittent rain as they filled the square in front of the towering symbol of the postwar division of Germany that is becoming a monument to the rapprochement of East Germany and West Germany. East German Premier Hans Modrow met West Germany Chancellor Helmut Kohl at the border for the 3 p.m. (9 a.m. EST) ceremony, then they walked together into East Germany. They were nearly mobbed by the crowd as they walked to a platform in front of the gate to address the exulting Berliners. Kohl called the occasion ``a fantastic thing.'' Thousands drenched by the rain uncorked champagne and danced atop the Berlin Wall, the once impregnable concrete barrier that is quickly crumbling. The opening was televised live in both countries. ``This is where the heart of Berlin pounds,'' said a commentator for West Germany's ZDF network. Two banners were unfurled near the new crossings to protest the killings of demonstrators in Romania. ``The last time I was here was as a kid when I used to play on this very spot. I never thought I'd come here again, it's really wonderful,'' said Peter Rebachmann, 42, of East Berlin. ``What a beautiful Christmas present. I am so elated that I can experience this,'' said a middle-aged woman. The crowd cheered and set off firecrackers when East German workers started dismantling the wall Thursday night. The workers used a crane to remove the rounded top of the wall. ``This is an experience that will go down in history. The gate was a symbol of division of Germany,'' said Jozef Polak, a West Berlin mechanic. More than 10,000 people had jammed the western side for the two sections of the wall to fall down. Some climbed on trees to get a better view. More people kept arriving throughout the night. A loud cheer sounded through the night air as the East German crane lifted a 3{-foot-wide segment of the concrete to make the first hole in that part of the wall shortly after midnight. The two new crossing points are 15 feet wide each. One is for Westerners going into East Berlin, the other for East Germans going to West Berlin. Although more than 20 border crossings have been made at the wall since East Germany opened its borders to the West on Nov. 9, the Brandenburg Gate has the most symbolic meaning for Berliners. The 200-year-old gate, Berlin's most famous landmark, remained on the eastern side when East Germany's Communist authorities built the Berlin Wall in 1961. Graffiti on the western side at one of the segments to be removed said, ``One day every wall must fall down.'' Friedhelm Brinkman, a salesman from Dortmund, West Germany, said he drove 360 miles to see the event. ``This was the central place in Berlin where everything happened (before the war). I always thought this place would be opened again and that's why I came tonight,'' he said late Thursday. Some people in the crowd shouted, ``Germany, United Fatherland,'' _ the rallying call of East German supporters of German unification.
The crowd was kept well away from the wall by barricades and cordons of West Berlin police to prevent them from possibly trying to cross the wall. After East Germany's dramatic opening of the borders, thousands of people danced on the section of the Berlin Wall at Brandenburg Gate. Crowds pulled down one segment of the wall in unforgettable scenes seen on television worldwide. Thousands of people had waited in vain for the gate to be opened in the first few days after the Berlin Wall started crumbling down in the wake of East Germany's peaceful revolution. Kohl and Modrow announced the agreement to open the two crossings when Kohl visited Dresden on Wednesday. The gate, the size of a five-story building on top of which is a bronze chariot with the goddess Victoria, was the backdrop for Hitler's rise to power and his last stand. It was also where East German workers began a 1953 uprising that was crushed by Soviet tanks. In East Berlin, the famous Unter den Linden boulevard ends at the gate. On the Western side, the sprawling avenue that leads to the gate was renamed June 17 Street, after the date of the uprising. Nazi brown shirts staged a triumphant torch parade through the gate when Adolf Hitler was named chancellor on Jan. 30, 1933. In the final days of World War II, the six-column sandstone gate was heavily damaged as Soviet tanks closed in on Hitler's bunker in the chancellory. It marked the border between the Soviet and British sectors when the victorious allies divided conquered Berlin into four sectors.
